Message.Title: Yahoo "news" attack on 401K private retirement accounts
Message.Msg: The 401K plans are those which employees save for and manage themselves. Each person with 401K has their own private accounts and they know they will get it. This just ticks the leftists off at the Yahoo "news" media dept who beleives government should control everything. 401Ks work and are secure unlike the FAILED SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM which has been looted by Democrats who give the funds away to illegal immigrants. So Yahoo, what retirement benefits do you provide your own employees? We know Yahoo rakes in about $13 billion annually but not a cent goes to the common share holder. We can safely assume that Yahoo is screwing their own employees too.

Topic.Title: Loeb backs Yahoo's Alibaba cash move - source

Message.Msg: I wonder if it really is unintended. Price deflation is such a natural consequence of such an announcement that it seems to me they must have known it would result. And cheaper prices means that YAHOO can buy more shares with whatever money they allocate to that.

Message.Msg: Yhoo has low debt and good cash on hand. which together with the proceeds of the alibaba sale would be plenty of money to give a one time dividend of say $1.00 per share and have more than enough to do some M+A . and CAP EX Yahoo pays no dividends and there has been no appreciation in the pps and it just took a big hit to the downside. IMO its going to treasde sideways for a long time --Not a good place to park your money.

Message.Title: Alibaba Group Holdings has plans for an IPO in the works
Message.Msg: Tmall is just as much Dangdang's competitor as Amazon China is, and Tmall is nearly 25 times as large. Alibaba Group Holdings, of which Tmall is a subsidiary and Yahoo oowns 43% of, has plans for an IPO already in the works.

Topic.Title: Alright already.So there is no dividend.

Message.Msg: Why do people want one time cash dividend? What ever the "dividend" is one can expect the price to drop proportionately, hence no real gain for the shareholders. What does it do for the company, outside of satisfy folks who are looking to cash out, it really does nothing. In contrast, if you buy back shares with the money the pps should rise proportionately, and if you invest it wisely (like the Alibaba investment in the first place) you will gain net value for the company. It seems to me that those wanting the cash dividend are simply trying to cash out but don't want to sell their shares/ This makes no sense. If you thing yahoo is going nowhere then simply sell and move on (you can move sideways with a dividend with MSFT (little risk) or you can bet on apple contining its upward flight, you can bet on gold, or you can simply hold cash. If yahoo has a future (and recent history leaves this a major question mark) then it should invest to grow not through the money to the wind!!!!

Topic.Title: Alright already.So there is no dividend.

Message.Msg: So what!! You should care about how the money is used unless you have no interest in Yahoo or hold a short position and want to see it drop further. If you honestly feel that sending out cash dividents is what is best for a company fine. Now, if they had 40 billion and had no idea what to do with the money then fine, trim the holdings and distribute some funds. But, yahoo needs to find its identity and get itself kickstarted. AND the have resources that had been locked up with which to do it. So do something constructive with the money!!! IMO, the market overreacted. Why would any honest person downgrade Yahoo at this point, particularly after the market reaction. They still have ALL of the assets, and they have a new CEO who needs to have the flexibility to make wise decisions. I think it is a sign that they have a CEO who can think.

Message.Title: Yes, There Is Good Reason For Disappointment In The CEO's Reevaluation Effort!!!
Message.Msg: When a company's shareholders have no way of gaining appreciation, but through appreciation of the share stocks price and the company is valued way less than at its peak years ago and there are no regular divedends, then denying participation in benefits from a one time sale of an appreciated asset takes away what is seen as a deserved pay out to the shareholder. Not only that, but the angst among share holders who are hearing nothing now on what they thought would be at least some sort of a return has caused them to lose 6% in recent share value(from $16+ To $15 in just a day so far). What a terrible decision to throw up in the air the payout from what is less than half of the possible appreciation from the Aisian Assets!!!! Heck, if the CEO wants some money to play with then she should bring the other sale opportunities to a successful conclusion and be able to work with that money for reinvestment, but for pete's sake reward the shareholders who have been more than patient; with some of the appreciation sooner than later!!!

Message.Msg: before yahoo and cnbc teamed up.....cnbc took shots at yahoo at every opportunity.....now they play nice

Topic.Title: Yes, There Is Good Reason For Disappointment In The CEO's Reevaluation Effort!!!

Message.Msg: So the board appoints a new CEO from an aggressive competitor and you think she is going to return cash to shareholders. Heck no! From the start it was obvious that she intends to build Yahoo into her vision of the company, not sit back as a caretaker CEO handing out cash like Yahoo is some type of REIT. The capital return to shareholders was part of the Levinsohn and Morse Interim CEO deal. Once that ended in an Outsiders hire as CEO, and especially as the architect of that deal left. (With the CFO not far behind it seems) no one should have been surprised at what happened. I am not so surprised that longs posting here were caught off guard, they've been caught off guard for years by Yahoo's moves. It is all of the professional investors that didn't see this coming that amazes me. When it comes to Yahoo, always do the opposite of what conventional wisdom says and you will profit.

Topic.Title: Liberal Nuts now running Yahoo?

Message.Msg: Hey, a little balanced commentary is okay. But things seem to be going only one way at Yahoo, and these days it's a bad idea for a business to alienate potential customers and clients. However, it's beginng to appear that Yahoo is on its way into internet oblivion, so maybe none of it matters. The new CEO is probably in town for a brief stay -- long enough to decide there's not much that can be done, so selling the company to Google will become the way to wind down Yahoo's operations.

Topic.Title: What YHOO will buy!

Message.Msg: When I look at the trading chart and pattern of buying in YHOO, I see someone buying the heck out of this stock. Since there is no reports of insider buying, which requires within three business days a report to SEC of such purchases, I can only assume it is the company its self buying under their (already filed with the SEC) plan to buy 5B in stock. The only other option is a new investor or investors buying under the 5% threshold for reporting and we wont know until the end of the quarter from where the buying is coming. But just look at the chart and you can see it is there, relentless and agressive buying!

Message.Title: PREVARICATORS
Message.Msg: Yahoo's corporate culture is one of lying. The employees lie to the managers; the managers lie to the board of directors; everybody lies to the shareholders. Since nobody expects to be around very long, nobody expects to be called to account and nobody is. I have email going back several years from Customer Care, various managers and even two former board members stating that they are very concerned about the serial spam on the message boards and they are only months away from implementing a new computer program that will stop it. They all lied. They are still issuing unlimited ID's to serial spammers who try to steal from Yahoo users and even reported spam messages are not being deleted. We just elected a new board of directors based on the statement that assets would be sold and money returned to shareholders. Instead, they hired a young, ambitious CEO. Although it has yet to be proven, I'm guessing they lied as well. Some companies know that truth and fair play works - my exprience with Amazon, Apple and even American Express is quite good. Some companies really need a cultural shift. Like Yahoo. Unfortunately, I don't see it happening.
